title: Trump outlines plans for running Venezuela | ABC NEWS
description: American forces have seized Venezuela's President NicolÃ¡s Maduro and his wife in a major military attack in the country's capital, Caracas.  US President Donald Trump says the US will run Venezuela until a new government is installed.  Mr Maduro and wife Cilia Flores are being taken to New York to face a "narco-terrorism" trial, the US president says.  The international community has offered mixed reactions, from congratulations in Israel to condemnation in Russia. title: The events that led to Maduro's capture | ABC NEWS
description: Deposed Venezuelan president Nicolas Maduro and his wife Cilia Flores have touched down in New York after being captured by US special forces in Caracas. Operation Absolute Resolve marks a dramatic escalation in tensions between Washington and Caracas since US President Donald Trump returned to power.  From attacks on alleged drug boats to an oil blockade of Venezuela, the ABC takes a look back at the events that led to the capture of the Venezuelan leader. title: US captures Venezuelan President NicolÃ¡s Maduro and his wife in early morning raid | ABC NEWS
description: The US has captured Venezuelan President NicolÃ¡s Maduro and his wife during an early morning raid, which saw US military strike targets within the capital Caracas and several other states.  US President Donald Trump said Mr Maduro was taken by special operations forces and whisked by helicopters to the Iwo Jima, an amphibious assault ship in the Caribbean, ahead of his transfer to New York.  The US president says his country "will run" Venezuela for the forseeable future but was vague on details on how exactly that would happen.  Fauziah Ibrahim and Johanna Nicholson, ABC News Channel. Social version by David Douglas Stuart for the ABC News Social Media Team.   ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. description: US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth hailed what he called an "historic" overnight US raid in Venezuela and underscored President Donald Trump's aim of reasserting US dominance in the Western Hemisphere and "getting back the oil that was stolen from us." title: Pinball enthusiast Greg boasts 50 rare machines in his backyard shed | ABC NEWS

title: Amid a population crisis, this island needs migrants to keep its industry alive | ABC NEWS
description: Japan is renowned as the world's most homogeneous society, but a reluctance to open up to migration has led to a super-aged, shrinking society. Many industries are now struggling to find workers. But for one small community, multiculturalism has proven to be the answer. North Asia correspondent James Oaten travelled to the island of Etajima. title: 34-year-old man drowns at Jervis Bay along NSW South Coast | ABC NEWS
description: A man has drowned at Green Patch beach in Jervis Bay on the NSW South Coast. Police say multiple people were pulled from the water when the 34-year-old died. description: A group of researchers is calling on the South Australian government to commit to universal vision checks for all preschool-aged children. title: US captures and detains Venezuelan president in extraordinary military operation | ABC NEWS
description: An extraordinary US military raid has stunned the world with US President Donald Trump ordering military strikes on Venezuela and the capture of the country's president Nicolas Maduro. The operation was planned and rehearsed for months, but carried out in just a few hours. Maduro has been moved to a New York detention centre awaiting trial on drugs and weapons charges. There's been shock and condemnation from around the world, but on the streets of Caracas, some Venezuelans are celebrating the end of the Maduro regime. title: Sports stars back royal commission into Bondi attack in open letter | ABC NEWS
description: Dozens of Australian sports stars have joined calls for a federal royal commission in response to the Bondi terror attack. Ian Thorpe, Michael Clarke, Lleyton Hewitt, and Jess Fox are among those signing an open letter backing the inquiry. The Albanese government has stood firm on its position, saying it has other plans in place to address antisemitism.
